options.D: Posterior pigmented epithelium of the sclera

questions.explanation: The lamina fusca is the innermost layer of the sclera.

questions.question: The sclera is the thinnest at which of the following locations?

options.C: Anterior to the attachment of the superior rectus
options.D: Posterior to the attachment of the superior rectus

questions.explanation: The sclera is the thinnest posterior to the insertion of the rectus muscles. The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, with maximum thickness around the optic nerve, 0.66 mm at the insertions of the rectus muscles and 0.33 mm beneath the rectus muscles and thinnest behind their insertions.

questions.question: A patient sustained a severe blow to the right eye from the lateral side during a fistfight. The eyeball is soft to touch and a rupture of the sclera is suspected. What is the least likely site of rupture?
questions.explanation: The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture. Traumatic scleral rupture, or globe rupture, occurs after blunt-force trauma. It usually occurs due to the compression force of the trauma. It therefore likely occurs at the insertion of rectus muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact. Rupture at the site of trauma, in this case lateral limbus, is rare. The major signs of scleral rupture are conjunctival edema and subconjunctival hemorrhage, hyphema, ocular hypotony, impairment or dislocation of the lens, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.

questions.question: What is the predominant type of collagen in the sclera?
questions.explanation: Collagen type I is the predominant type of collagen found in the sclera.Collagen forms 50 to 75% of the dry weight of the sclera. Type II is absent in the sclera. It is foundin the vitreous body of the eye.124

questions.question: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the outer tunics of the eyeball such ascornea and sclera, thereby resulting in their ectasia (bulging) which is known asstaphyloma. Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.Staphyloma is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion ofthe cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weakcornea or sclera.Types of Staphyloma:TypesAnterior staphylomaPathologyDue to bulging of the pseudocornea, internally lined by the iris & externally by the newly formed epithelium.Intercalary staphylom Due to bulging of weakened 1aCiliary staphylomaEquatorial staphylomaPosterior staphylomaimbal tissue at the limbus, internally lined by the root of iris & the anterior most part ofthe ciliary bodyDue to bulging of the weakened sclera, internally lined bythe ciliary body, can extend up to 8mm behind the limbusDue to bulging of sclera withchoroidal lining, seen around14 mm behind the limbus, inthe equatorial regionDue to bulging of sclera linedby the choroid, seen behindthe equatorCausesSloughing corneal ulcerDevelopmental glaucomaSecondary angle closure glaucomaHealing of perforating injuryPeripheral corneal ulcer.Scleritis End stage glaucomaPerforating injuriesScleritisChronic uncontrolledglaucomaScleral degeneration in pathological myopiaPosterior scleritis Pathologica1 myopiaPerforating injuriesAnterior-Anatomical types of staphylomaOMARROW125-IntercalaryCiliaryEquatorialPosteriorKeratoconus (Option A) is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder due to defectivesynthesis of mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue. It usually starts at puberty and progressesslowly, not associated with risk factors like glaucoma. Therefore, we can rule out keratoconus inthis patient.

questions.question: The ciliary staphyloma is due to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Ciliary staphyloma is due to scleritis.Ciliary staphyloma is the ectasia (bulging) of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects theciliary zone that includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It can be caused by scleritis,absolute glaucoma or trauma to the ciliary region of the eye.The image below shows ciliary staphyloma with scleritis.

questions.question: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Whichof the following condition commonly causes this?119
questions.explanation: Irritation in the eye associated with areas of scleral thinning through which the uvea shines issuggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation.Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity of thesclera is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.Other collagen disorders associated with it are as follows:•Wegener's granulomatosis (option B)• Polyarteritis nodosa (option A)•Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)•Ankylosing spondylitis• Relapsing polychondritis127

questions.question: The most common type of scleritis is
questions.explanation: Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis is the most common type of scleritis.Scleritis can be classified into anterior and posterior scleritis. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera infront of the equator, while posterior scleritis affects the sclera behind the equator of the eye.Anterior scleritis is further classified into the following types:••Non-necrotizingDiffuse: The most common variety• Nodular: Scleral nodules are present. Annular scleritis is a variant in which the scleral nodulesare arranged in a ring around the limbus.• Necrotizing• With inflammation• Without inflammation: Also known as scleromalacia perforans. It is seen in elderly females withlong-standing rheumatoid arthritis.The image below shows anterior nodular scleritis.

questions.question: All the following statements are true for a 40-year-old diagnosed with scleritis except-Scleromalacia perforans is associated with systemic disease.b) Pain is not a prominent feature.c) Glaucoma may occur.d) Retinal detachment is a known complication.120Question 11:A 63-year-old woman presented with a two-week history of gradually worsening sharp andstabbing left eye pain with redness. The severe pain kept her awakened during the night. Oninvestigation, B-scan ultrasound shows the 'T' sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenonspace. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Pain is a prominent feature of scleritis.Scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera. Patients present with moderate to severe eye pain,redness, lacrimation and photophobia. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equatorand may lead to the following complications:• Acute infiltrative stromal keratitis•⚫ Sclerosing keratitis• Peripheral ulcerative keratitis128• Uveitis• Glaucoma•• Hypotony (rarely phthisis)• Perforation of the scleraPosterior scleritis involves the sclera behind the equator and may lead to uveal effusion withchoroidal detachment, disc edema, proptosis or exudative retinal detachment.Scleromalacia perforans is a type of anterior scleritis. It typically occurs in elderly women withrheumatoid arthritis (systemic disease). There is ischemia and necrosis of the sclera; however,there is no inflammation. Clinically, it is a painless condition with a white eye. Areas of thinnedout sclera through which the uvea shines are seen in such patients.

questions.question: A patient develops surgically induced necrotising scleritis following an ocular surgery. Thepatient most likely underwent any of the following surgeries except:
questions.explanation: Surgically induced necrotizing scleritis (SINS) may occur following any ocular surgery involvingthe creation of a scleral wound. Tarso-frontalis sling surgery is a lid surgery and does not involvethe sclera.SINS is a condition of scleral inflammation and necrosis that may occur as a complication of thefollowing surgeries:• Pterygium excision• Cataract surgery (especially with sclero-corneal tunnel)•⚫ Trabeculectomy• Vitreo-retinal surgeries⚫ Squint surgerySINS is more likely to develop in those with rheumatoid arthritis, connective tissue disorders orfollowing intra-operative use of mitomycin C. It is treated with NSAIDS and systemic steroids.

questions.question: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you come across a child with the followingpresentation. Which of the following disorders is it associated with?121
questions.explanation: The child has blue sclera which is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.Blue scleral discoloration is due to scleral thinning. The underlying uvea thus becomes prominentand visible. Osteogenesis imperfecta (types I and IIA) and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type VI) arethe most commonly associated diseases. Both diseases are inherited disorders of collagenformation.Other options:130Option A: Hemochromatosis occurs due to iron deposition in various tissues. Rusty-brownperilimbal conjunctiva and scleral discoloration are seen.Option C: Congenital ocular melanocytosis occurs due to an increase in the number, size andpigmentation of melanocytes. Sclera is multifocal slate-grey pigmented.Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis may present with extraarticular manifestations such as secondarySjogren's syndrome where keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be seen.

questions.question: The sclera is thick in all the following conditions except-
questions.explanation: The sclera is not thick in buphthalmos.The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, 0.66mm thick at the insertion of recti and 0.33mm thickbeneath the recti. In buphthalmos, the sclera is stretched and thinned out, resulting in "bluesclera." Buphthalmos refers to an enlarged eyeball due to congenital glaucoma.

questions.question: An intern comes across a 7-year-old girl with the following features. All the following arecomponents of her condition except-122
questions.explanation: The given scenario of a young girl with facial asymmetry, deviation of angle of the mouth, flatnasal bridge, preauricular tags and limbal dermoid (lenticular yellow tumour at the limbus) of theeye is suggestive of Goldenhar syndrome. Lung hypoplasia is not a component of this syndrome.Goldenhar syndrome or oculoauriculovertebral spectrum is a congenital developmental anamolyaffecting structures derived from the first branchial arch. It has the following features:••Systemic:Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions•Macrostomia and microtia• Preauricular and facial skin tags••Hemivertebrae (usually cervical)• Mental handicapCardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies.• Ocular:• Dermoid• Upper lid notching or coloboma.Microphthalmos•Disc coloboma131
